questions.text:
Om̐ namo bhagavate vāsudevāya||

Janmādyasya yato'nvayāditarataścārtheṣvabhijñaḥ svarāṭ tene brahma hṛdā ya ādikavaye muhyanti yatsūrayaḥ|
Tejovārimṛdāṁ yathā vinimayo yatra trisargo'mṛṣā dhāmnā svena sadā nirastakuhakaṁ satyaṁ paraṁ dhīmahi||1||

wordByWordMeaning.bhagavate: To the Lord, the Supreme Being.
wordByWordMeaning.vāsudevāya: To Vāsudeva, an epithet of Lord Kṛṣṇa.
wordByWordMeaning.janmādyasya: From whom the creation, etc., of the universe arises.
wordByWordMeaning.itarataḥ: And also in the opposite way.
wordByWordMeaning.trisargaḥ: Threefold creation (based on three Guṇas: Sattva, Rajas, Tamas).

questions.overallMeaning: Let us meditate upon the Supreme Truth, who is free from illusion and exists eternally in His own divine abode. He is the self-sufficient ruler, fully cognizant of all things, and the source of creation, sustenance, and dissolution. It is He who revealed Vedic knowledge to the first-born sage, Brahmā, though even the greatest sages remain bewildered by His divine play. Just as fire, water, and earth appear to interchange, so does the material creation emerge, though it is ultimately under His supreme control.

questions.text: Dharmaḥ projjhitakaitavo'tra paramo nirmatsarāṇāṁ satāṁ vedyaṁ vāstavamatra vastu śivadaṁ tāpatrayonmūlanam| Śrīmadbhāgavate mahāmunikṛte kiṁ vā parairīśvaraḥ sadyo hṛdyavarudhyate'tra kṛtibhiḥ śuśrūṣubhistatkṣaṇāt||

wordByWordMeaning.projjhita-kaitavaḥ: completely rejecting all materially motivated religion
wordByWordMeaning.nirmatsarāṇām: for the pure-hearted, free from envy
wordByWordMeaning.satām: of the devotees or saintly persons
wordByWordMeaning.tāpatraya-unmūlanam: uprooting the threefold miseries (adhyātmika, adhidaivika, adhibhautika)

questions.overallMeaning: This verse from Śrīmad Bhāgavatam declares that this scripture completely rejects all materially motivated religion and presents the supreme path of truth for pure-hearted devotees. It reveals the real, eternal substance, which bestows ultimate welfare and removes all threefold miseries of material existence. The Bhagavatam, compiled by the great sage Vyāsa, makes the Supreme Lord directly available in the hearts of those who sincerely hear it with devotion, rendering other scriptures unnecessary.

questions.text: Nigamakalpatarorgalitaṁ phalaṁ śukamukhādamṛtadravasaṁyutam| Pibata bhāgavataṁ rasamālayaṁ muhuraho rasikā bhuvi bhāvukāḥ||3||

wordByWordMeaning.bhāvukāḥ: those full of devotion and poetic sentiment.

questions.overallMeaning: Oh connoisseurs of divine sentiment and poetry! Drink again and again the nectar-like essence of the Śrīmad Bhāgavatam, which is the ripened fruit of the wish-fulfilling tree of the Vedas. This sacred scripture, having fallen from the mouth of Sage Śuka, is imbued with the immortal nectar of divine wisdom. Absorb its essence until the very end, for it grants liberation and eternal bliss.

questions.text: Nāmiṣe'nimiṣakṣetre ṛṣayaḥ śaunakādayaḥ| Sattraṁ svargāya lokāya sahasrasamamāsata||4||

wordByWordMeaning.animiṣa: the One who does not wink, an epithet of Viṣṇu.
wordByWordMeaning.śaunakādayaḥ: beginning with Śaunaka (i.e., Śaunaka and others).
wordByWordMeaning.svargāya: for attaining heaven, the celestial world.

questions.overallMeaning: In the sacred region of Naimiṣa, a place associated with Animiṣa (Lord Viṣṇu), the great sages, led by Śaunaka, performed a grand Soma sacrifice (Sattra) that lasted for a thousand years. Their purpose was to attain the celestial world, a realm of divine bliss beyond the temporary heavens of Indra.

questions.text: Ta ekadā tu munayaḥ prātarhutahutāgnayaḥ| Satkṛtaṁ sūtamāsīnaṁ papracchuridamādarāt||5||

wordByWordMeaning.ekadā: one day, at a certain time.
wordByWordMeaning.huta-huta-agnayaḥ: having offered oblations to the sacrificial fire.
wordByWordMeaning.sūtam: Sūta (a narrator of epics and puranas).

questions.overallMeaning: One day, in the early morning, after offering oblations into the sacred fire, the revered sages honored Sūta, who was seated among them. With great respect and reverence, they inquired about a significant matter.

questions.text: Tvayā khalu purāṇāni setihāsāni cānagha| Ākhyātānyapyadhītāni dharmaśāstrāṇi yānyuta||6||

wordByWordMeaning.sa-itihāsāni: and the Itihāsas (epic histories like Mahābhārata and Rāmāyaṇa).

questions.overallMeaning: The sages said: 'O sinless one, you have indeed narrated and studied the Purāṇas, the Itihāsas (such as the Mahābhārata and Rāmāyaṇa), and the scriptures that expound Dharma. You are well-versed in these sacred texts.'

questions.text: Yāni vedavidāṁ śreṣṭho bhagavānbādarāyaṇaḥ| Anye ca munayaḥ sūta parāvaravido viduḥ||7||

wordByWordMeaning.vedavidām: among the knowers of the Vedas.
wordByWordMeaning.bādarāyaṇaḥ: Bādarāyaṇa (Vyāsa, the compiler of the Vedas and Purāṇas).
wordByWordMeaning.parāvara-vidaḥ: knowers of the distant and the near, or of the past and future.

questions.overallMeaning: O Sūta, the revered sage Bādarāyaṇa (Vyāsa), the foremost among the knowers of the Vedas, along with other sages who possess the wisdom of both the manifest and the unmanifest, or the past and the future, also knew these sacred scriptures.

questions.text: Vettha tvaṁ saumya tatsarvaṁ tattvatastadanugrahāt| Brūyuḥ snigdhasya śiṣyasya guravo guhyamapyuta||8||
questions.overallMeaning: O gentle one, you truly know all this by the grace of the sages. The gurus certainly reveal even the most secret and profound knowledge to a devoted and loving disciple.

questions.text: Tatra tatrāñjasāyuṣmanbhavatā yadviniścitam| Puṁsāmekāntataḥ śreyastannaḥ śaṁsitumarhasi||9||
questions.overallMeaning: Therefore, O long-lived one, whatever you have ascertained with certainty in this matter, please tell us, as it is invariably conducive to the ultimate welfare of humankind.

questions.text: Prāyeṇālpāyuṣaḥ sabhya kalāvasminyuge janāḥ| Mandāḥ sumandamatayo mandabhāgyā hyupadrutāḥ||10||
questions.overallMeaning: O noble one, in this age of Kaliyuga, people are generally short-lived, lazy, slow-witted, unfortunate, and undoubtedly afflicted by various troubles such as diseases and calamities.

questions.text: Bhūrīṇi bhūrikarmāṇi śrotavyāni vibhāgaśaḥ| Ataḥ sādho'tra yatsāraṁ samuddhṛtya maniṣayā| Brūhi bhadrāya bhūtānāṁ yenātmā suprasīdati||11||

wordByWordMeaning.śrotavyāni: to be heard, to be studied.
wordByWordMeaning.bhadrāya: for the benefit, for the welfare.
wordByWordMeaning.bhūtānām: of all living beings, of creatures.
wordByWordMeaning.ātmā: the self, the soul, the mind.
wordByWordMeaning.suprasīdati: becomes fully pleased, attains complete peace.

questions.overallMeaning: There are numerous scriptures and extensive duties described in them, each divided into different sections. Therefore, O holy one, please extract the essence of these teachings through your wisdom and share it for the welfare of all living beings. By doing so, the self (ātmā) will attain complete peace and satisfaction.

questions.text: Sūta jānāsi bhadraṁ te bhagavānsātvatāṁ patiḥ| Devakyāṁ vasudevasya jāto yasya cikīrṣayā||12||

wordByWordMeaning.bhagavān: the Fortunate One, the Supreme Lord (Krishna).
wordByWordMeaning.sātvatām: of the Sātvatas, of the devotees, of the Yadu dynasty.
wordByWordMeaning.cikīrṣayā: with the intention, with the purpose.

questions.overallMeaning: O Sūta, may prosperity be upon you! You know the divine intention with which the Supreme Lord, the protector of the Sātvatas (devotees and Yadu dynasty), was born as the son of Vasudeva and Devakī.

questions.text: Tannaḥ śuśrūṣamāṇānāmarhasyaṅgānuvarṇitum| Yasyāvatāro bhūtānāṁ kṣemāya ca bhavāya ca||13||

wordByWordMeaning.tat: that, this (referring to the divine story).
wordByWordMeaning.śuśrūṣamāṇānām: of those who are eager to listen, desiring to hear.
wordByWordMeaning.arhasi: you are worthy, you are fit.
wordByWordMeaning.anuvarṇitum: to narrate, to describe in detail.
wordByWordMeaning.bhūtānām: of living beings, of all creatures.

questions.overallMeaning: O revered Sūta! Please narrate to us, who are eager to listen, about that divine incarnation, whose descent is solely for the welfare and prosperity of all living beings.

questions.text: Āpannaḥ saṁsṛtiṁ ghorāṁ yannāma vivaśo gṛṇan| Tataḥ sadyo vimucyeta yadbibheti svayaṁ bhayam||14||

wordByWordMeaning.saṁsṛtim: cycle of birth and death, transmigration.

questions.overallMeaning: One who has fallen into the dreadful cycle of birth and death, if he utters the divine Name—even involuntarily—he is immediately freed from it. Indeed, fear itself is afraid of that Name.

questions.text: Yatpādasaṁśrayāḥ sūta munayaḥ praśamāyanāḥ| Sadyaḥ punantyupaspṛṣṭāḥ svardhunyāpo'nusevayā||15||

wordByWordMeaning.sūta: O Sūta! (a respectful address to the speaker).

questions.overallMeaning: O Sūta! The tranquil sages who have taken refuge in His feet purify others immediately upon contact, just as the waters of the sacred Ganges purify, though only with repeated use.

questions.text: Ko vā bhagavatastasya puṇyaślokeḍyakarmanaḥ| Śuddhikāmo na śṛṇuyādyaśaḥ kalimalāpaham||16||

wordByWordMeaning.bhagavataḥ: of the Fortunate One, the Supreme Lord.
wordByWordMeaning.kalimala: impurity of Kali Yuga (age of discord).

questions.overallMeaning: Who, indeed, desiring purification, would not listen to the glorious fame of the Supreme Lord, whose deeds are praised by sacred verses and who removes the impurities of Kali Yuga?

questions.text: Tasya karmāṇyudārāṇi parigītāni sūribhiḥ| Brūhi naḥ śraddadhānānāṁ līlayā dadhataḥ kalāḥ||17||

wordByWordMeaning.sūribhiḥ: by wise and learned beings, sages.
wordByWordMeaning.śraddadhānānām: of those who have faith, devoted ones.
wordByWordMeaning.kalāḥ: primary forms (such as Brahmā, Rudra, etc.).

questions.overallMeaning: His exalted deeds, which are glorified by wise sages, manifest as divine pastimes. O wise one, please narrate them to us, the faithful, especially about His primary forms such as Brahmā and Rudra, which He assumes in His divine play.

questions.text: Athākhyāhi harerdhīmannavatārakathāḥ śubhāḥ| Līlā vidadhataḥ svairamīśvarasyātmamāyayā||18||

wordByWordMeaning.vidadhataḥ: of the one who performs, enacts.
wordByWordMeaning.svairam: freely, according to His own will.

questions.overallMeaning: O wise one, please narrate the auspicious stories of Lord Hari’s incarnations. His divine pastimes are enacted freely by the Supreme Lord through His own divine power (Māyā).

questions.text: Vayaṁ tu na vitṛpyāma uttamaślokavikrame| Yāchṛṇvatāṁ rasajñānāṁ svādu svādu pade pade||19||

wordByWordMeaning.uttamaśloka: the Highly Renowned One (Lord Viṣṇu), whose praises are sung in supreme verses.
wordByWordMeaning.rasajñānām: for those who are connoisseurs of divine taste (Rasa).

questions.overallMeaning: Indeed, we never become satiated with the glorious exploits of the Highly Renowned One (Lord Viṣṇu). For those who listen and are connoisseurs of divine taste, these pastimes become sweeter and sweeter at every moment.

questions.text: Kṛtavānkila karmāṇi saha rāmeṇa keśavaḥ| Atimartyāni bhagavāngūḍhaḥ kapaṭamānuṣaḥ||20||

wordByWordMeaning.keśavaḥ: Keśava (an epithet of Kṛṣṇa, meaning 'one with beautiful hair').

questions.overallMeaning: Indeed, the Fortunate One (Bhagavān), known as Keśava, along with Balarāma, performed superhuman deeds, all while remaining hidden in a deceptive human form.

questions.text: Kalimāgatamājñāya kṣetre'sminvaiṣṇave vayam| Āsīnā dīrghasattreṇa kathāyāṁ sakṣaṇā hareḥ||21||

wordByWordMeaning.kṣetre: in the sacred place, in the field.
wordByWordMeaning.sattreṇa: by (performing) a sacrifice, a Vedic ritual.
wordByWordMeaning.kathāyām: in the story, in the discourse.

questions.overallMeaning: Recognizing that Kaliyuga has arrived, we are seated in this sacred place of Viṣṇu, engaged in a long sacrificial ritual, with the leisure to listen to the divine stories of Hari.

questions.text: Tvaṁ naḥ sandarśito dhātrā dustaraṁ nistitīrṣatām| Kaliṁ sattvaharaṁ puṁsāṁ karṇadhāra ivārṇavam||22||

wordByWordMeaning.dhātrā: by divine providence, by the Lord.

questions.overallMeaning: You have appeared before us by divine providence, like a helmsman guiding those who wish to cross the vast and unconquerable ocean of Kaliyuga, which robs people of their goodness.

questions.text: Brūhi yogeśvare kṛṣṇe brahmaṇye dharmavarmaṇi| Svāṁ kāṣṭhāmadhunopete dharmaḥ kaṁ śaraṇaṁ gataḥ||23||

wordByWordMeaning.brahmaṇye: the pious one, related to sacred knowledge.
wordByWordMeaning.dharmavarmaṇi: the one who is like an armor for Dharma.

questions.overallMeaning: Now that Krishna, the pious Lord of Yoga and protector of Dharma, has entered His own highest Abode, tell us—where has Dharma taken refuge?

questions.text: Iti śrīmadbhāgavate mahāpurāṇe prathamaskandhe naimiṣeyopākhyāne prathamo'dhyāyaḥ||1||

wordByWordMeaning.naimiṣeyopākhyāne: in the narrative related to Naimiṣa forest.

questions.overallMeaning: Thus ends the first chapter of the first canto in the Naimiṣeya narrative of the great Purāṇa, Śrīmad Bhāgavatam.
